titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 4641, ESTABLISHING PAIN MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES INTER-AGENCY TASK FORCE, AND PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 5046, COMPREHENSIVE OPIOID ABUSE REDUCTION ACT...

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 4641, ESTABLISHING PAIN MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES INTER-AGENCY TASK FORCE, AND PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 5046, COMPREHENSIVE OPIOID ABUSE REDUCTION ACT...; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 74

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Providing for the establishment of an inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 4641, to provide for the establishment of an inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication, by a yea-and-nay vote of 412 yeas to 4 nays, Roll No. 184.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Energy and Commerce now printed in the bill �D489�shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Brownley (CA) amendment (No. 1 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that adds the Office of Women's Health;<P/>Brooks (IN) amendment (No. 2 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that requires that any physician, dentists, non-physician prescriber or pharmacist who becomes a member of the Pain Management Best Practices Inter-Agency Task Force shall currently be licensed and practicing in their appropriate State;<P/>Grayson amendment (No. 3 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that ensures that ``first responders'' are included for membership on the Pain Management Best Practices Inter-Agency Task Force;<P/>Clark (MA) amendment (No. 4 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that adds to the Task Force an expert in adolescent and young adult addiction, and a person in recovery from addiction to medication for chronic pain whose addiction began in adolescence or adulthood, and directs the Task Force to consider the distinct needs of adolescents and young adults in its development of best practices;<P/>Pallone amendment (No. 5 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that adds representatives of Veteran Service Organizations to the Pain Management Best Practices Inter-Agency Task Force;<P/>Nolan amendment (No. 6 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that inserts a representative on the task force for active duty military, armed forces personnel, and veteran health and prescription opioid addiction;<P/>Watson Coleman amendment (No. 7 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that inserts a minority health expert as a representative to the Pain Management Best Practices Inter-Agency Task Force established by this bill;<P/>Kuster amendment (No. 8 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that requires that the task force research addiction trends in communities with high rates of prescription drug abuse;<P/>Schiff amendment (No. 9 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that requires the Inter-Agency Task Force, as part of its duties to review and update best practices for pain management strategies, to also take into consideration the coordination of information collected from State prescription drug monitoring programs for the purpose of preventing the diversion of pain medication;<P/>Clark (MA) amendment (No. 10 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that directs the Task Force to consider work done and any public comments submitted regarding electronic prescribing of opioids and its potential benefits, in the course of developing best practices;<P/>Rothfus amendment (No. 11 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that requires the inter-agency task force, as part of its review and update of best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication, to also take into consideration the practice of co-prescribing the overdose reversal drug naloxone;<P/>Clark (MA) amendment (No. 12 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that directs the Task Force to consider, in the course of developing best practices, Federal agency programs and research relative to substance use and substance use disorders among adolescents and young adults, as well as any gaps identified by Federal government programs or researchers in the prevention of, treatment for, and recovery from substance use by and substance use disorders among adolescents and young adults;<P/>Esty amendment (No. 13 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that requires the inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication, specifically as it pertains to physician education and consumer education;<P/>Welch amendment (No. 14 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that expands the task force report to include information and recommendations on developing new non-opioid forms of pain relief; and<P/>Sessions amendment (No. 15 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that ensures the task force takes into consideration existing private sector, State, and local government efforts related to pain management and prescribing pain medication.<P/>H. Res. 720, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 4641) and (H.R. 5046) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 255 ayes to 163 noes, Roll No. 183, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 215 yeas to 173 nays, Roll No. 182.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Providing for the establishment of an inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication

Rept. 114-551) that requires the inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication, specifically as it pertains to physician education and consumer education;<P/>Welch amendment (No. 14 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that expands the task force report to include information and recommendations on developing new non-opioid forms of pain relief; and<P/>Sessions amendment (No. 15 printed in part A of H. Rept. 114-551) that ensures the task force takes into consideration existing private sector, State, and local government efforts related to pain management and prescribing pain medication.<P/>H. Res. 720, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 4641) and (H.R. 5046) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 255 ayes to 163 noes, Roll No. 183, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 215 yeas to 173 nays, Roll No. 182.

titleInfo.title: ESTABLISHING PAIN MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES INTER-AGENCY TASK FORCE

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Providing for the establishment of an inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 4641, to provide for the establishment of an inter-agency task force to review, modify, and update best practices for pain management and prescribing pain medication, by a yea-and-nay vote of 412 yeas to 4 nays, Roll No. 184.

congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Improving Safe Care for the Prevention of Infant Abuse and Neglect Act
Improving Safe Care for the Prevention of Infant Abuse and Neglect Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measures:<P/>H.R. 4843, amended, to amend the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to require certain monitoring and oversight, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 421 yeas with none voting ``nay'', Roll No. 185;

The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measures:<P/>H.R. 4843, amended, to amend the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to require certain monitoring and oversight, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 421 yeas with none voting ``nay'', Roll No. 185;

titleInfo.title: ENERGY AND WATER DEVELOPMENT AND RELATED AGENCIES APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2016

extension.searchTitle: ENERGY AND WATER DEVELOPMENT AND RELATED AGENCIES APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2016; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 74

congVote.result: Three-fifths of the Senators duly chosen and sworn not having voted in the affirmative, the motion is rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Energy and Water Development and Related Agencies Appropriations Act_Agreement
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Senate continued consideration of H.R. 2028, making appropriations for energy and water development and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2016, taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:<P/>Alexander/Feinstein Amendment No. 3801, in the nature of a substitute.<P/>Alexander (for Flake/McCain) Amendment No. 3876 (to Amendment No. 3801), to require that certain funds are used for the review and revision of certain operational documents.<P/>During consideration of this measure today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 57 yeas to 42 nays (Vote No. 67), three-fifths of those Senators duly chosen and sworn, not having voted in the affirmative, Senate rejected the motion to close further debate on McConnell (for Cotton) Amendment No. 3878 (to Amendment No. 3801), of a perfecting nature.

congVote.result: Three-fifths of the Senators duly chosen and sworn having voted in the affirmative, the motion is agreed to.
The PRESIDING OFFICER. Under the previous order requiring 60 votes for the adoption of this amendment, the amendment is rejected.
The PRESIDING OFFICER. Under the previous order requiring 60 votes for the adoption of this amendment, the amendment is rejected.
